task: Concatenate all MF4 files in C:\Users\ADMIN\Downloads\ev-data-pack-v10\ev-data-pack-v10\electric_cars\log_files\Tesla Model 3\LOG\3F78A21D\00000001 folder save the concatenated MF4 file with name Tesla_Model_3_3F78A21D.mf4 in the same folder path

plan.reasoning: Get current desktop state to find running applications and verify if asammdf is available
Activate the asammdf application window so subsequent UI queries and clicks target it
Capture asammdf UI elements (menu bar, Mode menu) and obtain coordinates for the Mode menu
Open the 'Mode' menu to switch to Batch processing (coordinates resolved from previous State-Tool output)
Find the 'Batch processing' menu item coordinates in the opened Mode menu
Select 'Batch processing' mode (coordinates resolved from previous State-Tool output)
Allow the UI to switch to Batch processing mode
Capture the Batch processing view to locate the 'Add files' button
Re-capture the current UI to have a fresh state snapshot (will be referenced as STATE_1). This confirms what is actually available before taking any corrective clicks.

The 'Add files' button was not present in the captured Batch view. The File menu is visible in the current state (Control Name: File). Open the File menu to look for a menu action that opens the file selection dialog (likely 'Add files', 'Open', or similar).
Allow the File menu to open and the UI to settle so the next State capture sees the menu items.
Capture the opened File menu (will be referenced as STATE_12) so we can locate the exact menu item that triggers the Open File dialog (we will look for names like 'Add files', 'Open', or 'Import').
Re-capture the current UI (STATE_13) to verify nothing changed since the failure and to have a fresh baseline before taking corrective actions.

The File menu is visible in the captured state and contains a visible 'Open' menu item (control at coordinates [1338,78]). Instead of trying to click the non-existent 'Add files' item, click the 'Open' menu item to open the file selection dialog (KB 'open_files' indicates File→Open works in Batch mode to select multiple files).
Allow the Open File dialog to appear and the UI to settle.
Capture the newly opened Open File dialog (STATE_16) so we can locate the filename/address input and the dialog 'Open' button precisely.

Focus the filename/address input in the Open File dialog. Use the edit control(s) discovered in STATE_16. The loc is expressed as prioritized references to likely edit controls in the captured dialog; the executor will pick the first existing one to focus the path field.

Enter the full folder path with a wildcard (*.mf4) into the dialog's path/filename field and press Enter so the dialog lists/selects all MF4 files in the target folder (matches original intent to add all MF4 files).
Allow the Open dialog to resolve the path and populate the file list after the Enter key.
Re-capture the Open File dialog (STATE_20) to locate the dialog's 'Open' button (or equivalent) so we can confirm and add the selected files to the Batch list.

Click the dialog's Open (or equivalent confirm) button to add the selected MF4 files to the Batch processing list. We reference likely button names from STATE_20 and use a prioritized list so the executor chooses an existing control.
Allow the Batch processing view to populate with the selected files after confirming the dialog.
Capture the Batch processing view (STATE_23) to verify the files were added and to locate the Concatenate tab and its controls.
Ensure the 'Concatenate' tab is selected. The tab item 'Concatenate' was visible earlier at coordinates [1334,113] in the current UI snapshot; explicitly select it to ensure its controls are shown.
Allow the Concatenate tab contents to render and controls to become interactive.

Capture the Concatenate tab contents (STATE_26) to find the output filename/path input field and confirm the location of the 'Concatenate' start button. This identifies the exact controls we must interact with.
Focus the output filename/path input field using the edit control discovered in STATE_26. We reference multiple likely control names to robustly find the correct edit control.
Enter the full output path and required filename so the concatenated MF4 will be saved in the same folder with the requested name.
Capture the Concatenate tab again (STATE_29) to ensure the output filename/path was set and to locate the actionable 'Concatenate' button before starting the operation.

Click the 'Concatenate' action button to start the concatenation. The Batch view previously showed a Button named 'Concatenate' at coordinates [1669,996]; use that confirmed coordinate to begin processing.
Final capture (STATE_31) to check batch status messages, confirmations, or the Batch list for a success indicator and to verify the concatenated file has been created.

[RECOVERY PLAN]
Completed 12 steps successfully.
Recovery reasoning: 1) What the original plan ASSUMED vs what ACTUALLY exists: The original plan assumed an 'Add files' menu item inside the File menu / Batch view would be present. The actual captured UI (STATE_12) shows that 'Add files' does not exist. Instead, the File menu contains an 'Open' item (control present at [1338,78]) and the Batch view already exposes an explicit 'Concatenate' tab and a 'Concatenate' button. The failure happened because the automation tried to click a non-existent 'Add files' menu item.

2) Intent of the failed action: The intent was to open a file-selection dialog that allows adding multiple MF4 files into the Batch list so they can be concatenated and saved to a single MF4 file in the same folder.

3) Actual elements found to achieve the same intent: The File→Open menu item is visible and is a supported path to open multiple files in Batch mode (KB 'open_files'). The Batch view's Concatenate tab and the Concatenate button are visible. These elements provide an alternate, valid route to add files and perform the concatenation.

4) How KB guidance informed the new approach: The knowledge base explicitly lists File→Open as the supported method to open one or more MDF/MF4 files, and confirms this is viable in Batch processing mode. Using File→Open replaces the missing 'Add files' menu item and aligns with the app's documented behavior.

5) Which pending steps were reused/adapted: Many of the original pending steps remain valid: waiting for the Open dialog, capturing the dialog to locate filename/address and Open buttons, entering the target folder path with a wildcard (*.mf4), confirming the selection, ensuring the Concatenate tab is selected, setting the output filename, and pressing the Concatenate action. These were reused but adapted to use the actual 'Open' menu item (which exists) as the trigger instead of the missing 'Add files'. Additional State-Tool calls were inserted at key points to dynamically discover dialog controls and confirm UI changes before clicking.

6) Why this approach will succeed: This plan uses only UI elements confirmed present in the captured state (the visible 'Open' menu item and the 'Concatenate' tab/button). It replaces the unsupported assumption ('Add files') with the supported File→Open path from the KB. The plan includes repeated State-Tool captures before interacting with dialog/edit controls so the automation always acts on actual, discovered controls rather than guessed names. Prioritizing the discovered control references (e.g., multiple possible edit/button names in the STATE references) makes the plan robust to minor localization or naming differences. Finally, the plan ends with a final state capture (STATE_31) to verify success and detect any errors reported by the application.
Total steps in merged plan: 31
